title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0001
text: What is an object in Java?
explanation: An object is an instance of a class that contains data and methods.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0002
text: Which keyword is used to create an object in Java?
explanation: The 'new' keyword is used to create an object in Java.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0003
text: Which of the following is true about objects?
explanation: Objects store both data (fields) and behavior (methods).

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0004
text: Which of the following is true about object references?

options.text: They store the memory address of the object

explanation: Object references store the memory address of the object in the heap.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0005
text: Where are objects stored in memory?
explanation: Objects are stored in the heap memory, while references are stored in the stack.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0006
text: Which of the following is true about object creation?

options.text: Objects are created using the 'new' keyword
Objects are created using constructors only
Objects are created using static methods only

explanation: Objects are created using the 'new' keyword, which calls the constructor.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0007
text: Which of the following is true about object initialization?
explanation: Constructors are used to initialize objects when they are created.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0008
text: Which of the following is true about object references?

options.text: Multiple references can point to the same object
Each reference points to a unique object

explanation: Multiple references can point to the same object in memory.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0009
text: Which of the following is true about null references?

options.text: They do not point to any object
They point to a default object
They point to the Object class

explanation: A null reference does not point to any object in memory.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0010
text: What happens when an object reference is set to null?

options.text: The object becomes eligible for garbage collection
The object is moved to the stack

explanation: When an object reference is set to null, the object becomes eligible for garbage collection.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0011
text: Which of the following is true about the 'this' keyword?

options.text: It refers to the current object
It refers to the parent object
It refers to the static context
It refers to the class itself

explanation: The 'this' keyword refers to the current object of the class.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0012
text: Which of the following is true about object equality?
explanation: The '==' operator compares references, while equals() compares object content.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0013
text: Which of the following is true about the Object class?

options.text: It is the superclass of all classes in Java
It is a subclass of String

explanation: The Object class is the root superclass of all classes in Java.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0014
text: Which of the following methods is defined in the Object class?
explanation: The Object class defines methods like toString(), equals(), and hashCode().

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0015
text: Which of the following is true about the toString() method?

options.text: It returns a string representation of the object

explanation: The toString() method returns a string representation of the object.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about the equals() method?

options.text: It compares the content of two objects
It compares the memory addresses of two objects

explanation: The equals() method compares the content of two objects for equality.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about the hashCode() method?

options.text: It returns an integer hash code for the object

explanation: The hashCode() method returns an integer hash code for the object.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about object cloning?

options.text: It creates a copy of an existing object

explanation: Object cloning creates a copy of an existing object using the clone() method.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0019
text: Which interface must a class implement to allow cloning?
explanation: A class must implement the Cloneable interface to allow cloning.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about garbage collection?
explanation: Garbage collection automatically deletes unused objects to free memory.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0021
text: Which method is called by the garbage collector before destroying an object?
explanation: The finalize() method is called by the garbage collector before destroying an object.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0022
text: Which of the following is true about object references in Java?

options.text: They can be reassigned to another object

explanation: Object references can be reassigned to point to another object.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about object comparison using '=='?
explanation: The '==' operator compares the memory addresses of two object references.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about object comparison using equals()?
explanation: The equals() method compares the content of two objects for equality.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about object serialization?

options.text: It converts an object into a byte stream

explanation: Serialization converts an object into a byte stream for storage or transmission.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0026
text: Which interface must a class implement to allow serialization?
explanation: A class must implement the Serializable interface to allow serialization.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about object deserialization?

options.text: It reconstructs an object from a byte stream

explanation: Deserialization reconstructs an object from a byte stream.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about object identity?

options.text: Two references pointing to the same object have the same identity
Two objects with the same content have the same identity
All objects have the same identity

explanation: Object identity means two references point to the same memory location.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about object state?

options.text: It is defined by the values of its fields
It is defined by its methods
It is defined by its class name
It is defined by its memory address

explanation: The state of an object is defined by the values of its instance variables.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about object behavior?

options.text: It is defined by the methods of the class
It is defined by the fields of the class
It is defined by the constructor
It is defined by the memory address

explanation: The behavior of an object is defined by the methods of its class.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about object lifetime?

options.text: It begins when the object is created and ends when it is garbage collected
It begins when the class is loaded
It begins when the program starts
It ends when the program ends

explanation: An object's lifetime starts when it is created and ends when it is garbage collected.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about object references and garbage collection?

options.text: An object is eligible for garbage collection when no references point to it
An object is deleted immediately when set to null
An object is never garbage collected
An object is garbage collected when equals() returns false

explanation: An object becomes eligible for garbage collection when no references point to it.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about object arrays?

options.text: They can store multiple objects of the same type
They can store only primitive types
They can store objects of different types

explanation: Object arrays can store multiple objects of the same type.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about object casting?

options.text: It converts one object type to another compatible type

explanation: Object casting converts one object type to another compatible type.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about upcasting?

options.text: It converts a subclass reference to a superclass reference
It converts a superclass reference to a subclass reference

explanation: Upcasting converts a subclass reference to a superclass reference.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about downcasting?

options.text: It converts a superclass reference to a subclass reference
It converts a subclass reference to a superclass reference

explanation: Downcasting converts a superclass reference to a subclass reference.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about instanceof operator?

options.text: It checks whether an object is an instance of a class

explanation: The instanceof operator checks whether an object is an instance of a specific class.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about object immutability?

options.text: Immutable objects cannot be modified after creation

explanation: Immutable objects cannot be modified after creation; String is an example.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about object mutability?

options.text: Mutable objects can be modified after creation

explanation: Mutable objects can be modified after creation, such as StringBuilder.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about object references and methods?

options.text: Objects are passed by reference in Java
Objects are passed by value of reference
Objects cannot be passed to methods

explanation: Objects are passed by value of reference, meaning the reference is copied.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about object arrays and inheritance?

options.text: An array of superclass type can hold subclass objects
An array of subclass type can hold superclass objects

explanation: An array of superclass type can hold subclass objects due to polymorphism.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about object references and null pointer exceptions?

options.text: Accessing a null reference causes a NullPointerException
Null references are converted to empty objects

explanation: Accessing a null reference causes a NullPointerException in Java.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about object pooling?

options.text: It reuses objects to improve performance

explanation: Object pooling reuses objects to reduce memory allocation overhead.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about wrapper objects?

options.text: They wrap primitive types into objects
They are used only for strings
They are used for arrays only

explanation: Wrapper classes wrap primitive types into objects, e.g., Integer, Double.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about autoboxing?

options.text: It automatically converts primitives to wrapper objects
It converts wrapper objects to primitives

explanation: Autoboxing automatically converts primitives to wrapper objects.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about unboxing?

options.text: It automatically converts wrapper objects to primitives
It converts primitives to wrapper objects

explanation: Unboxing automatically converts wrapper objects to primitive types.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about object references and static members?

options.text: Static members belong to the class, not to any object
Static members belong to each object
Static members are deleted with objects

explanation: Static members belong to the class itself, not to any specific object.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about object references and methods?

options.text: Methods can be called using object references
Methods cannot be called using object references

explanation: Instance methods can be called using object references.

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about object creation using reflection?

options.text: Objects can be created dynamically using Class.newInstance()

explanation: Reflection allows dynamic object creation using Class.newInstance().

title: JavaOOPObjects - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes an object in OOP?

options.text: A real-world entity with state and behavior

explanation: An object represents a real-world entity with state (fields) and behavior (methods).
